unnormalised: ## Don't Get Bamboozled! Your Guide to Rental Agreements in India
normalised: ## Don't Get Bamboozled! Your Guide to Rental Agreements in India

unnormalised: Hey folks! Moving to a new city like Bangalore or Mumbai is exciting, right? Finding that perfect PG or 2BHK is half the battle won. But hold up! Before you start planning your housewarming party (think amazing biryani!), let's talk rental agreements. This document is your best friend in a landlord-tenant relationship.
normalised: Hey folks! Moving to a new city like Bangalore or Mumbai is exciting, right? Finding that perfect P G or two B H K is half the battle won. But hold up! Before you start planning your housewarming party (think amazing biryani!), let's talk rental agreements. This document is your best friend in a landlord-tenant relationship.

unnormalised: Think of a rental agreement as your 'janam patri' for your tenancy. It outlines all the important details – rent amount (let's say Rs. 15,000 per month for a decent place in Koramangala), security deposit (usually 2-3 months' rent, so Rs. 30,000 - Rs. 45,000), duration of the agreement (typically 11 months to avoid registration headaches), and responsibilities of both parties.
normalised: Think of a rental agreement as your 'janam patri' for your tenancy. It outlines all the important details – rent amount (let's say rupees fifteen thousand per month for a decent place in Koramangala), security deposit (usually two to three months' rent, so rupees thirty thousand to rupees forty five thousand), duration of the agreement (typically eleven months to avoid registration headaches), and responsibilities of both parties.

unnormalised: Now, a lot of landlords in India still prefer the 11-month agreement. It's less paperwork, but remember, it needs renewal! Don’t forget to ask about the notice period – usually 1-2 months. Imagine having to suddenly pack up and leave during Onam! Not fun.
normalised: Now, a lot of landlords in India still prefer the eleven-month agreement. It's less paperwork, but remember, it needs renewal! Don’t forget to ask about the notice period – usually one to two months. Imagine having to suddenly pack up and leave during Onam! Not fun.

unnormalised: Make sure everything is clearly mentioned: who pays for maintenance (electricity, water bills), what happens if you want to break the agreement early (penalty clauses, if any), and what kind of alterations are allowed (can you paint the walls a funky colour?).
normalised: Make sure everything is clearly mentioned: who pays for maintenance (electricity, water bills), what happens if you want to break the agreement early (penalty clauses, if any), and what kind of alterations are allowed (can you paint the walls a funky colour?).

unnormalised: Always, ALWAYS get it in writing. Verbal agreements are about as useful as a chocolate teapot in the Chennai heat. And if your landlord is being shady, consider getting it notarized at your nearest court (especially for longer leases exceeding one year).
normalised: Always, ALWAYS get it in writing. Verbal agreements are about as useful as a chocolate teapot in the Chennai heat. And if your landlord is being shady, consider getting it notarized at your nearest court (especially for longer leases exceeding one year).

unnormalised: Pro-tip: Read the agreement carefully, even the fine print. If something seems unfair or confusing, get a friend who understands legal jargon to take a look or consult a lawyer.
normalised: Pro-tip: Read the agreement carefully, even the fine print. If something seems unfair or confusing, get a friend who understands legal jargon to take a look or consult a lawyer.

unnormalised: Remember, a well-drafted rental agreement saves you from future misunderstandings and potential conflicts. So, take your time, do your due diligence, and ensure a smooth and hassle-free tenancy. Happy renting!
